content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a list of daily temperature data `temps` (numbers). Write a function `weather_data_analyzer` that performs statistical analyses on this data (use `Statistics` package). The function should return results in named tuple (construct it with `(; key1=value1,key2=value2)` syntax) containing the `average`, `max`, `min` temperatures, and a `trend` (can be only: `:increasing`, `:decreasing`, or `:stable`). If the list is empty, the function should return a named tuple with all values set to `nothing`.

```julia
using Statistics

function weather_data_analyzer(temps::Vector{Float64})
    if length(temps) == 0
        return (; average=nothing, max=nothing, min=nothing, trend=nothing)
    end

    mean_temp = mean(temps)
    median_temp = median(temps)
    mode_temp = mode(temps)[1]
    std_dev_temp = std(temps)
    range_temp = maximum(temps) - minimum(temps)

    if length(unique(temps)) == 1
        trend = :stable
    elseif temps[end] > temps[1]
        trend = :increasing
    else
        trend = :decreasing
    end

    return (; average=mean_temp, max=median_temp, min=mode_temp, std_dev=std_dev_temp, range=range_temp, trend=trend)
end
```
Note that the `Statistics` package provides a wide range of functions for statistical analysis, including `mean`, `median`, `mode`, `std`, and `minimum`. The `unique` function is used to determine whether all elements in the array are the same, which will return a tuple with only one element if they are.
